text: {bc}a person or way of behaving that is seen as a model that should be followed

examples.text: He was inspired by the {it}example{/it} of his older brother. [=he wanted to do what his older brother did]
You should try to follow her {it}example{/it}. [=try to do as she does]
Let that be an {it}example{/it} to you! [=let that show you what you should or should not do]
He set a good/bad {it}example{/it} for the rest of us.
It's up to you to {phrase}set an example{/phrase}. [=to behave in a way that shows other people how to behave]
She chooses to {phrase}lead by example{/phrase}. [=to lead by behaving in a way that shows others how to behave]

text: {bc}someone or something that is mentioned to help explain what you are saying or to show that a general statement is true

examples.text: She gave/offered several {it}examples{/it} to show that the program is effective.

text: {bc}something or someone chosen from a group in order to show what the whole group is like

examples.text: We've chosen three {it}examples{/it} of contemporary architecture for closer study.
a classic {it}example{/it} of a Persian rug
a fine/prime {it}example{/it} of the artist's work

text: {bc}a phrase or sentence that shows how a word is used

examples.text: The dictionary includes thousands of {it}examples{/it}.

text: {bc}something (such as a problem that a student has to solve) that is used to teach how a rule or process works

examples.text: arithmetic {it}examples{/it}

examples.text: The scandal is a {phrase}textbook{/phrase} [={it}classic, perfect{/it}] {phrase}case/example{/phrase} of corporate greed.

follow the line of least resistance
follow the path of least resistance

text: {bc}to go or come after or behind (someone or something)

examples.text: She {it}followed{/it} us into the kitchen.
The dog {it}followed{/it} the children home.
The exit is right this way. Just {it}follow{/it} me.
The children went home and the dog {it}followed{/it} behind.
If one sheep goes through the gate, the rest will {it}follow{/it}.

text: {bc}to go after or behind (someone) secretly and watch to find out what happens

examples.text: He hired a private detective to {it}follow{/it} his wife everywhere. [=to secretly find out where she went and what she did]
{it}follow{/it} a suspect
I think that someone is {it}following{/it} us. = I think we're being {it}followed{/it}.

text: {bc}to come after (something) in time or place or as part of a series

examples.text: Spring {it}follows{/it} winter. = Winter {it}is followed{/it} by spring.
The number 15 {it}follows{/it} 14.
Her accident was {it}followed{/it} by a long period of recovery.
First came the student speeches, and the presentation of awards {it}followed{/it}.
({it}formal){/it} The war ended. {phrase}There followed{/phrase} [={it}then came{/it}; then there was] a long period of rebuilding.

text: {bc}to have or do something after (something else)
{bc}to happen after and as a result of (something)

examples.text: Rioting {it}followed{/it} the unjust verdict.
If you work hard, success will/must surely {it}follow{/it}.

text: {bc}to be true or seem to be true because of something

examples.text: From the evidence given, several conclusions {it}follow{/it}. = Several conclusions {it}follow{/it} from the evidence given. [=we can make several conclusions based on the evidence given]

text: {bc}to be guided by (something)

examples.text: You should {it}follow{/it} [={it}obey{/it}] your conscience.
{it}follow{/it} your instincts
{it}follow{/it} my advice
She must learn to {it}follow{/it} instructions.
We must {it}follow{/it} the evidence wherever it leads.
You should {phrase}follow her example{/phrase}. = You should {it}follow{/it} the example she set. [=you should do what she did]

text: {bc}to do the same thing as (someone)

examples.text: She {it}followed{/it} her father (by going) into medicine. = She {it}followed{/it} her father by becoming a doctor.

text: {bc}to move forward on (a road, a path, etc.)

examples.text: {it}Follow{/it} that path, and you will come to a log cabin.
You should {it}follow{/it} the main highway until you see signs for the stadium.

text: {bc}to be on or next to (something) for a distance

examples.text: The path {it}follows{/it} the river pretty closely.
The road {it}follows{/it} the curve of the hill.

text: {bc}to keep your eyes or attention on (something)

examples.text: {it}Follow{/it} the bouncing ball.

text: {bc}to give close attention to what happens in (something)

examples.text: He {it}followed{/it} her career with interest.
{it}follow{/it} football
The book {it}follows{/it} his political career from its humble beginnings to his election as president.

text: {bc}to be a fan of (a team) {bc}{sx|support||}

examples.text: He {it}follows{/it} Manchester United.

text: {bc}to understand the sense or logic of (something or someone)

examples.text: I found it hard to {it}follow{/it} the twists and turns of the movie's complicated plot.
I'm sorry—I don't {it}follow{/it} your argument/reasoning. = I'm sorry—I don't {it}follow{/it} you. [=I don't understand you]
I'm sorry—I don't {it}follow{/it}. [=I don't understand]

text: {bc}someone or something that has been so successful that it is very difficult for the person or thing coming next to be as good

examples.text: Yesterday's thrilling victory will be {it}a tough act to follow{/it}.

text: {bc}to go wherever (someone) goes

examples.text: The little boy {it}followed{/it} his mother {it}around{/it} all day.

examples.text: Jane played a spade, and Roger {it}followed suit{/it}.

text: {bc}to do the same thing that someone else has just done

examples.text: His brother went to medical school, and he {it}followed suit{/it}.

{bc}to complete an activity or process that has been started

examples.text: He always starts the school year off studying and working hard, but he doesn't {it}follow through{/it}. [=he doesn't continue to study and work hard]
He doesn't {it}follow{/it} his good intentions {it}through{/it}. [=although he makes plans to do things, he doesn't actually do them]

text: {bc}to keep your arms, legs, etc., moving after you hit or kick a ball {bc}to complete a stroke or swing
{dx}see also {dxt|follow-through||}{/dx}

examples.text: You should {it}follow through{/it} on your backhand.
Don't forget to {it}follow through{/it} when you putt.

text: {bc}to follow (something) with something similar, related, or additional
{bc}to try to get more information about (something)

examples.text: The police {it}followed up (on){/it} the leads.
The references in the book were too vague to {it}follow up{/it}.

text: {bc}to do something in response to (something) {bc}to take appropriate action about (something)
{dx}see also {dxt|follow-up||}{/dx}

examples.text: Police {it}followed up{/it} the complaints with several arrests.
He complained several times, but the police never {it}followed up{/it}.
He says that the police failed to {it}follow up on{/it} his complaints.

text: {bc}to go in a straight or obvious course

examples.text: Just {it}follow your nose{/it} until you get there; you can't miss it.

text: {bc}to proceed without a definite plan {bc}to do what seems right or best without careful planning

examples.text: You don't need my advice—just {it}follow your nose{/it}.

text: {bc}to go toward the place where a smell is coming from

examples.text: I {it}followed my nose{/it} to the kitchen, where dinner was cooking.

text: {bc}to guide someone to a place especially by going in front

examples.text: You {it}lead{/it} and we'll follow right behind you.

text: {bc}to go or be at the front part of (something)

examples.text: The veterans will {it}lead{/it} a parade down Main Street.

examples.text: The path {it}leads{/it} uphill.

a set of stairs that {it}leads{/it} down to the basement

text: {bc}to guide the actions of a person or group {bc}to be in charge of a person, group, activity, etc.

examples.text: We need to elect someone who can {it}lead{/it}.
bosses who {phrase}lead by example{/phrase} [=who show employees how they should act by acting that way themselves]

{it}lead{/it} [={it}direct{/it}] an orchestra

text: {bc}to cause (a person, group, etc.) to do something or to follow some course of action

examples.text: Her interest in art {it}led{/it} her into the field of art history.

text: {bc}to be first, best, or ahead in a race or competition

examples.text: the team that is currently {it}leading{/it} in the pennant race
At the end of the fourth inning, the Red Sox {it}led{/it} by two runs.
{it}lead{/it} a race

the team that is {it}leading{/it} the league [=the team that is in first place]
a batter who {it}leads{/it} the league in home runs [=who has hit more home runs than any other batter]
a runner who is {phrase}leading the pack/field{/phrase} [=a runner who is ahead of the group of other runners]

text: {bc}to go through (life) in a certain way {bc}to have (a specified kind of life)

examples.text: They chose to {it}lead{/it} [={it}live{/it}] a quiet life.
He {it}leads{/it} a peaceful existence.
It turned out that he had been {phrase}leading a double life{/phrase}. [=deceiving people about his life, not telling the whole truth about his life]
He has always {phrase}led a charmed life{/phrase}. [=he has always been lucky]
She needs to {phrase}lead her own life{/phrase}. [=she needs to make her own decisions about her life]

{it}led{/it} a spade

examples.text: I don't know this dance, so I'd prefer it if you {it}lead{/it}.

examples.text: The judge ruled that the lawyer was {it}leading{/it} the witness.

examples.text: She {it}led off{/it} [={it}started, kicked off{/it}] the presentation with a brief overview of the project.

text: {bc}to be the first batter in an inning

examples.text: He {it}led off{/it} with a walk. [=he was the first batter in his team's half of the inning and he was walked]

text: {bc}to cause (someone) to wrongly continue believing or doing something

examples.text: She was devastated when she found out that he didn't really love her, and had only been {it}leading{/it} her {it}on{/it}. [=he had been leading her to believe that he loved her]

text: {bc}to put (something) in a place or position

examples.text: Would you please {it}set{/it} [=({it}Brit{/it}) {it}lay{/it}] the table?

text: {bc}to cause (a clock) to show a particular time

examples.text: We {it}set{/it} the clocks ahead one hour for daylight saving time.

In the winter, she {it}sets{/it} the thermostat at/to 68 degrees.

text: {bc}to decide on or choose (something)

examples.text: I {it}set{/it} a goal (for myself) to lose 15 pounds by the end of the year.

text: {bc}to give (a particular price or value) to something

examples.text: An antiques appraiser {it}set{/it} the value of the chair at $500.

text: {bc}to give (a high value or importance) to something

examples.text: They {it}set{/it} a high value on their privacy. [=they value their privacy very highly]

text: {bc}to cause (something) to be accepted as an example, rule, etc. {bc}to establish (a standard, trend, etc.) for others to follow or try to copy

examples.text: They are improving the safety of their vehicles and {it}setting{/it} a higher standard for other companies (to follow).

text: {bc}to establish (a record) as the performance or achievement that is the best of its kind

text: {bc}to cause (someone or something) to be in a specified condition

examples.text: The slaves were {it}set{/it} free.

They {phrase}set{/phrase} the house {phrase}on fire{/phrase}. = They {phrase}set fire to{/phrase} the house. = (more formally) They {it}set{/it} the house afire/aflame/ablaze. [=they caused the house to begin burning]

{bc}to begin a journey

examples.text: We will {it}set forth{/it} [={it}set out{/it}] at dawn.

text: {bc}to explain or describe (something) in an organized way

examples.text: The author {it}sets forth{/it} [={it}states{/it}] the book's premise in its first two pages.

text: {bc}to explain or describe (something) so that it can be considered

examples.text: She has {it}set forward{/it} [={it}presented{/it}] an ambitious plan to fix the nation's health-care system.

text: {bc}to begin to be present, seen, etc.

{bc}to begin traveling

examples.text: We {it}set off{/it} for home.
They {it}set off{/it} in a different direction.
In the first chapter, the hero {it}sets off{/it} on a long voyage across the ocean.

text: {bc}to cause (something) to start or happen

examples.text: {it}set off{/it} an explosion
Her comments {it}set off{/it} [={it}touched off{/it}] a chain of events that led to two people losing their jobs.
The incident {it}set off{/it} a debate about how public land should be used.

text: {bc}to cause (something) to begin making noise

examples.text: The thick smoke {it}set off{/it} the school's fire alarms.
Your watch will probably {it}set{/it} the metal detectors {it}off{/it}.

text: {bc}to cause (fireworks, a bomb, etc.) to explode

examples.text: They were accused of {it}setting off{/it} the bomb that destroyed the building.
It was {it}set off{/it} by remote control.

text: {bc}to make (something) easy to see or notice

examples.text: The blue in your sweater {it}sets off{/it} [={it}accents{/it}] your eyes.
Bright yellow police tape {it}set off{/it} the area where the crime occurred.
a quote {it}set off{/it} by quotation marks

text: {bc}to cause (someone) to suddenly start yelling, crying, laughing, etc.

examples.text: I wonder what {it}set{/it} her {it}off{/it}.

text: {bc}to make (a person or animal) suddenly attack (someone)

examples.text: Police dogs were {it}set on{/it} the protesters.
She {it}set{/it} her friends {it}on{/it} him.

text: {bc}to begin traveling in a particular direction

examples.text: We got out of the car and {it}set out{/it} for the nearest gas station.
They {it}set out{/it} toward the east.

text: {bc}to start doing something {bc}to begin an activity or effort with a particular plan or purpose

examples.text: She {it}set out{/it} with the goal of going to the Olympics.

text: {bc}to explain or describe (something)

examples.text: In the article, the group {it}sets out{/it} the role of parents in a child's education.
He {it}set out{/it} the basic argument between the two groups.

text: {bc}to move and organize (a group of things) so that they can be seen or used

examples.text: We'll need to {it}set{/it} a few extra chairs {it}out{/it} for our guests.
They {it}set out{/it} maps and travel brochures for the tourists to take.

{bc}to begin doing something in an active and serious way

examples.text: We {it}set to{/it} and soon finished the work.

text: {bc}to prepare for something by putting things where they need to be

examples.text: We have one hour left to {it}set up{/it} for the party.
We had better start {it}setting up{/it}.

text: {bc}to create or establish (something) for a particular purpose

examples.text: A panel needs to be {it}set up{/it} to investigate the issue.
She hopes that in a few years she can {it}set up{/it} a private practice of her own.
A foundation was {it}set up{/it} for people with the disease.
The church {it}set up{/it} a school for the city's homeless children.
The hikers {phrase}set up camp{/phrase} [=they prepared an area where they could sleep outside] just before sunset.

text: {bc}to arrange and plan (an event or activity)

examples.text: I'll ask my secretary to {it}set up{/it} a meeting with our clients.
Let's {it}set up{/it} a time to get together.
He was the one who {it}set up{/it} the bank robbery.

text: {bc}to put (something) in an upright position

examples.text: They {it}set up{/it} flags along the street for the parade.
Help me {it}set{/it} the tent {it}up{/it}.

text: {bc}to make (a machine, system, etc.) ready to be used

examples.text: They {it}set up{/it} the movie camera next to the door.
This computer wasn't {it}set up{/it} to run so many programs at one time.

text: {bc}to cause (someone) to be in a bad situation or to appear guilty

examples.text: Those aren't his drugs. Someone must have {it}set{/it} him {it}up{/it}! [=framed him; made it look like the drugs were his]
He claimed he was {it}set up{/it} by the police.

text: {bc}to help (someone) feel healthy and full of energy

examples.text: She says that daily exercise has {it}set{/it} her {it}up{/it} to face the challenges of getting old.

text: {bc}to give (someone) a job, a place to live, etc.

examples.text: She {it}set{/it} me {it}up{/it} in a great apartment in the city.
He {it}set{/it} his son {it}up{/it} with a job at his company.

text: {bc}to do something that makes it likely or possible for (someone) to do, get, or experience something

examples.text: The team's excellent defense {it}set{/it} them {it}up{/it} to score the winning touchdown.

text: {bc}to cause (someone) to meet someone in order to start a romantic relationship

examples.text: {ldquo}How did you first meet your husband?{rdquo} {ldquo}My best friend {it}set{/it} us {it}up{/it}.{rdquo}

text: {bc}to try to make people believe that you are (something)

examples.text: She has {it}set herself up as{/it} the best alternative to the current administration.
He {it}sets himself up as{/it} a defender of the people, but he's really only interested in getting more power.

shortDefinitions: to put (something) in a place or position
to put (something) into the surface of something —often used as (be) set
to attach (something, such as a jewel) to a piece of jewelry or other decoration —often used as (be) set
